abstract.p: Roy Jones Jr to defend his world light-heavyweight championship against Eric Harding (M)

block.p: The best Roy Jones Jr. could come up with yesterday in hyping his next opponent, Eric Harding, was Harding's ability to avoid being knocked to the canvas.
''There has to be something good about him; he's never been down,'' Jones said. ''He's fought some pretty good people in that time.''
The best Roy Jones Jr. could come up with yesterday in hyping his next opponent, Eric Harding, was Harding's ability to avoid being knocked to the canvas.
''There has to be something good about him; he's never been down,'' Jones said. ''He's fought some pretty good people in that time.''

The 31-year-old Jones (42-1, 34 knockouts) will defend his undisputed light-heavyweight title against the 27-year-old Harding (19-0-1, 6 knockouts) on Sept. 9 in New Orleans. Jones, who will receive no money up front, will split the $34.95 pay-per-view fees with Muhammad Ali's children's charity. Harding will reportedly earn a guaranteed $500,000 to $700,000, by far his biggest payday.

The two fighters entered the Nike showroom in Lower Manhattan escorted by women in skimpy Mardi Gras costumes as zydeco music blared. Jones wore a blue floral print shirt, shorts, sneakers and a crown, which made him look like the winner of a sand-castle contest at the beach.
Jones, considered by many to be the best boxer in any division, is still pondering a move up to heavyweight. And he is still hunting for the great fight that will elevate him into a household name.
Harding, a left-handed counterpuncher, is probably not the man to push Jones there. He will, however, make good human-interest fodder.

Harding estimated he had been arrested 15 to 20 times on charges ranging from drug dealing to assault. He said he changed his criminal path when he was shot on a Philadelphia street at age 22 after a dispute with two men. The bullet ricocheted off his beeper, he said, and pieces of the beeper lodged in his right thigh and had to be removed.

Harding lives with his wife and three children in East Hartford, Conn. An affable fellow, the corn-rowed, bespectacled Harding was clearly enjoying his big break but said he was not intimidated by Jones.
Harding showed uncustomary ferocity in his last fight. He broke Antonio Tarver's jaw and ribs in earning a unanimous decision in a title elimination bout on June 23.

''You never know what you get with me,'' said Harding, the International Boxing Federation's top-ranked contender. ''It might be the slick boxer you can't hit, or it might be the guy who goes in to bang it out.''
